Starting 2023, four universities are pausing or ending their Elsevier subscription due to exorbitant pricing.

Elsevier's subscription was costing them ~10% of their Libraries' entire budget.

"Elsevier’s prices have increased each year and have outpaced inflation"...this is despite Elsevier having the highest profit margins of virtually any other industry or publisher.

Is academia facing a massive burnout crisis?

Academics are increasingly "reevaluating whether their jobs are worth the high cost to their personal well-being. They are less willing to continue in positions with oversized workloads, salaries that do not keep up with inflation, and inflexible policies."

48% of universities report that faculty turnover increased in 2022 and >70% of academics reported mental health difficulties in 2021

via https://www.apa.org/monitor/2023/01/trends-faculty-exiting-academia

title: Prevent unwanted Layout Shifts caused by Scrollbars with the scrollbar-gutter CSS property

last_post.content:
TIL you can prevent layout shift when changing from

overflow: hidden;

to

overflow: auto; /* or scroll */

by adding

scrollbar-gutter: stable;

to the container 🤯

No more hacky padding-and-JavaScript shenanigans! Thanks @bramus for sharing!

https://www.bram.us/2021/07/23/prevent-unwanted-layout-shifts-caused-by-scrollbars-with-the-scrollbar-gutter-css-property/

title: Will Europe’s Privacy Bill of Rights Ever Truly Be Enforced? – The Markup

last_post.content:
Europe’s landmark privacy law looks good on paper, but enforcement has been spotty. That’s why activist Tanya O’Carroll is taking Meta to court in the U.K. to assert her right to object to personalized advertising under Europe’s #GDPR.

“If the European gold standard data protection legislation doesn’t apply to data profiling and ad targeting by one of the biggest tech companies on Earth, then what does it apply to?” O’Carroll asks in today’s newsletter from @Julia.

https://themarkup.org/hello-world/2023/01/14/will-europes-privacy-bill-of-rights-ever-truly-be-enforced

On the subject of young people being nostalgic for things they never experienced, something I learned about recently that I found particularly interesting was this:

Some gen Z'ers learned that back in the day we had small web sites which tended to end in ~myusername.

They re-created some of those spaces, and refer to them as 'tilde clubs' (after the first one). Tiny little self-contained social spaces, often using minimal HTML and terminal access.

http://tilde.club

PyTorch is the most popular deep learning framework in research and is rapidly gaining adoption in industry.

Its core API is straightforward and can be learned in just two steps:
(1) defining the model and
(2) setting up the training loop.

I have a 3-minute video here to get you started -- it is definitely possible to get started over the weekend: https://lightning.ai/pages/courses/deep-learning-fundamentals/3-0-overview-model-training-in-pytorch/3-5-the-pytorch-api-parts-1-2/

https://datasette.io/plugins/datasette-faiss is a Datasette wrapper around Facebook Research's FAISS fast vector index - it dropped the time needed to brute-force compare 3,000 similarity vectors from 1.3s to 5ms

https://datasette.io/plugins/datasette-cookies-for-magic-parameters is a bit of an odd one: it lets you store parameters (such as API keys) in browser cookies rather than passing them in ?query-strings - to help avoid secrets being accidentally recorded in referrer or access logs

title: Catastrophe #88: The Texas Legislature Returns for a Brutal Year

last_post.content:
Other bills attempt to capitalize on the moral panic around #drag queens, simultaneously using it as a way to attack both #LGBTQIA culture as a whole and the ability of #transgender people to participate in public life. HB 643 from Representative Jared Patterson broadly seeks to ban anyone from “performing” in public when #children are present if the performer’s clothing doesn’t match conservative norms for their assigned #gender at birth. It’s so broadly written, in fact, that experts are concerned it could even ban #trans people from performing at major league sporting events or all-ages concerts. Venues found to be in violation would face misdemeanor charges. 

“That could literally mean a trans person doing standup at a comedy show would then turn it into a sexually oriented business,” @esqueer said.

From “Catastrophe 88” at @TexasObserver https://www.texasobserver.org/texas-legislature-preview-2023/

#txlege #Texas #news #politics #Fascism

title: Development of an Offline-Friend Addiction Questionnaire (O-FAQ): Are most people really social addicts? - Behavior Research Methods

last_post.content:
A fantastic way to make an important point. Researchers took items from widely-used scales of "social media addiction," and reworded them to be about spending time offline with friends. Using parallel criteria, they discovered that 69% of people are addicted to spending time with friends.

"Readers should approach our measure with a level of skepticism that should be afforded to current social media addiction measures."

(h/t @cconrymurray)

https://link.springer.com/article/10.3758/s13428-020-01462-9

title: Splitting the atomic scientists: how the Ukraine war ruined physics

last_post.content:
"In March 2022, the number of new research papers by the #LHC [Large Hadron Collider] experiments fell to zero. The reason: a lack of agreement on how to list Russian and Belarusian scientists and institutes, if at all. The temporary compromise, in place up to now, is not to publish."
https://www.theguardian.com/science/2023/jan/15/scientists-ukraine-war-cern-physics-large-hadron-collider

h/t @jocelyn_etienne

#cern #physics #war #ukraine #russia #belarus

For all you lovely data-wranglers:

Maybe you already know about reconciling in #OpenRefine - but did you know that it's very easy to run a local reconciliation-API?

"CSV-Reconcile helps you to join datasets that are messy, contain data about the same things but no unique identifiers by which you could join them."
https://okfnlabs.org/reconcile-csv/

This just saved me uncountable hours of work :heart_cyber:

#Data #DigitalHumanities #DigitalHistory #DataViz #DataVis

title: remembering horse_ebooks in the age of GPT3 - honor ash

last_post.content:
“so.. where was the charm? why was it better to consider a poetic attachment to something written by a bot, than cynically crafted by a human curator specifically for the purpose of having viral potential? why did we feel cheated, when we learnt that for just over two years, it had been the latter?” — a great post from @h — remembering horse_ebooks in the age of #GPT3

title: Speeding up the JavaScript ecosystem - module resolution

last_post.content:
"The slowness in our tooling wasn’t caused by JavaScript the language, but by things just not being optimized at all."

In part 2 of "Speeding up the JavaScript ecosystem" series @marvinh dives into #JavaScript module resolution libraries... and ends up speeding resolution-intensive tasks by 30%. Great stuff!

https://marvinh.dev/blog/speeding-up-javascript-ecosystem-part-2/

The Internet Transition, @robin

“we’re trying to run a planetary society that needs to solarpunk the fuck out of itself in a hurry on the collective intelligence of an 18th century principality that’s heard of the Enlightenment from some guy at the pub.”

https://berjon.com/internet-transition/
